image.altText: A uniformed officer and a man appear to be having a physical altercation in a backyard

props.synopsis: Convicted drug dealer Rhys Aaron Johns is suing SA Police for half a million dollars, claiming his arrest significantly damaged his left retina and left him with other permanent injuries requiring "facial reconstructive surgery".

title.children: Drug dealer claims police 'assaults' caught on camera left him with permanent injuries

image.altText: Kerry Reece and her husband Brendan sit at the kitchen table looking at insurance bills

props.synopsis: Kerry Reece has been loyal to her insurer for decades, but a new class action claims her loyalty might not have been rewarded — rather it has seen the bills of customers like her inflated, lawyers are alleging.

title.children: 'Kick in the guts': Lawsuit claims loyal insurance customers charged inflated premiums

image.altText: A mug shot of Peter Rex Dansie.

props.synopsis: Notorious killer Peter Dansie dies at the age of 75, seven years after his act of "ultimate evil", in which he murdered his wife Helen by pushing her wheelchair into a pond in Adelaide's parklands.

title.children: 'Evil and despicable' wife-killer Peter Dansie dies in custody seven years after Adelaide pond murder

image.altText: A woman smiles in front of the Sydney Harbor Bridge.

props.synopsis: Clifford Neumann admits to killing mother-of-five Victoria Ann Stewart whose death was one of several which prompted South Australia's upcoming royal commission into family and domestic violence.

title.children: Man pleads guilty to murder of Adelaide mother-of-five Victoria Stewart

image.altText: A man leans on crutches surrounded by debris from a damaged tent camp

props.synopsis: Officials on the ground in Gaza say that at least 12 of the people killed were women. The Israeli army denied it struck the area.

title.children: Second tent strike in Rafah kills 21 people, Israel denies involvement

image.altText: A side profile close up of Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's political survival as an opposition leader thus far is an impressive feat, but the issue of nuclear power could be one that damages his popularity with women, a new piece of research shows.

title.children: Peter Dutton's a political freak of nature, but is he about to nuke himself with women voters?

image.altText: A photo of people digging at the site of a landslide.

props.synopsis: The landslide that struck Papua New Guinea's Enga province came without apparent warning and while people slept. But can landslides be predicted? The answer could help prevent future deaths.

title.children: Why rescuing people from landslides is so risky

image.altText: A young woman smiling

props.synopsis: Aboriginal suicides in hospitals and anger over Victoria's efforts to Close the Gap are raised as the Yoorrook Justice Commission begins its new inquiry into health, housing and education.

title.children: Death of young Aboriginal woman at Melbourne hospital raised during truth-telling hearings

image.altText: "Leased" sign outside house

props.synopsis: Rental affordability in Australians capital cities is going from bad to worse. PropTrack's latest Market Insight Report shows surging rents over the past year have seen the number of affordable rentals "vanishing" across the country.

title.children: Catch 22 means 'pretty much no rental properties are affordable' in Australia

image.altText: a man in a business suit walks outside a court building

props.synopsis: Italian tourist Gabriele Cairo pleads guilty to causing the deaths of South Australian couple Cynthia and John Clark, and their daughter Jacquie, in a crash at a regional intersection in October.

title.children: Tourist pleads guilty over SA intersection crash that killed three members from same family

image.altText: Restaurant owner Deanna Flynn Wallis inside the tavern in Mount Barker.

props.synopsis: For many years, Deanna knew there was something about her that was "different". Now, she's taking part in a rollout of "quiet dinners" for people with sensory needs around food.

title.children: Adelaide Hills restaurant offers 'quiet dinners' and sensory-friendly menu for autistic community

image.altText: A large group of people gathers for a rally one sign says girls just want to feel safe

props.synopsis: The latest monthly crime statistics released by SA Police show 22 murders were reported across the state in the past year – a 69 per cent increase from the 13 murders reported in the year prior.

title.children: Crime statistics reveal murders, shoplifting on the rise in South Australia

image.altText: Cars line a highway

props.synopsis: NSW Police confirm a man has died after a head-on collision outside of Broken Hill, closing a section of the Barrier Highway for most of the day.

title.children: Man killed in head-on collision east of Broken Hill on Barrier Highway

image.altText: Whyalla steelworks owner Sanjeev Gupta

props.synopsis: GFG Alliance boss Sanjeev Gupta says the blast furnace — which has been offline since mid-March — has been restarted, and steelmaking should begin again next month.

title.children: 'Concrete progress': Whyalla steelworks blast furnace restarted

image.altText: A young blonde woman named Ariel Bombara sitting while being interviewed.

props.synopsis: The daughter of Mark James Bombara, who shot and killed Jennifer and Gretl Petelczyc in their Floreat home, says police were warned about her father's disturbing behaviour.

title.children: Daughter of Perth killer warned police three times he was an 'imminent threat'

image.altText: beef packaged in Japan

props.synopsis: On a recent visit to Tokyo, a New South Wales farmer was shocked to find Australian beef selling for less than you can find it in Coles and Woolworths.

title.children: 'It shows there is gouging': Farmer finds Australian beef selling cheaper in Japanese supermarket

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: Police ballistics specialist Paul Griffiths told the court he conducted tests to test the plausibility of Mr Lynn's account of events, but had not watched the police interview with the accused.

title.children: Shotgun alleged to have killed Carol Clay shown to jurors in Greg Lynn murder trial

image.altText: James Marape salutes as he walks past defence personnel outside parliament house.

props.synopsis: As one of Papua New Guinea's remote villages grapples with one of the worst natural disasters in its history, the prime minister is busy attending to his own political crisis.

title.children: A king and a US president sent their condolences to PNG. But where is the nation's own prime minister?

image.altText: a young girl smiling and holding an umbrella

props.synopsis: Kallista Mutten was questioned about her methamphetamine use during the six-week trial into the death of the nine-year-old in early 2022.

title.children: Charlise Mutten's mother breaks down in court after being accused of fatally shooting 9yo

image.altText: Payne Haas breaks through a tackle from Cameron Munster

props.synopsis: Payne Haas says he has never considered skipping the State of Origin since being named as a NSW Blues starter despite his father facing drug-trafficking charges and possibly the death penalty in the Philippines.

title.children: NSW star Haas focused on Origin despite father's arrest and risk of facing death penalty

image.altText: A man lays against the wall of a car park.

props.synopsis: Welcome to Portland, Oregon, the US city that decriminalised drugs and nearly immediately regretted it.

title.children: This progressive US state pioneered a radical drug policy, then overdose deaths skyrocketed

image.altText: Stock image of a Virgin plane

props.synopsis: Federal police arrest a man who allegedly ran naked down the aisle of a Virgin plane on a flight from Perth to Melbourne, knocking a crew member to the floor and forcing the aircraft to turn around.

title.children: Passenger arrested after allegedly running naked through Virgin plane, knocking over crew member

image.altText: A courtroom sketch of Christopher Healey, who is bald and wears a dark shirt.

props.synopsis: A man who tried to murder the sister of Federal MP Kate Chaney with an axe at the GP praictce where she worked is sentenced to 23 years behind bars.

title.children: Man who tried to kill MP Kate Chaney's sister with an axe sentenced to 23 years' jail

image.altText: Jane Hume at senate estimates

props.synopsis: Senators have spent the day debating transparency and "vexatious" questioning at estimates hearings.

title.children: Government handbook instructing bureaucrats to be 'vague' not useful, public servant tells Senate estimates

image.altText: Surrounded by shadows, Jordon Steele-John sits in the chamber.

props.synopsis: A staff member in Parliament House has had a seizure after the Department of Parliamentary Services denied requests to adjust lighting in their office.

title.children: Parliament worker has seizure after request for lighting change not acted on

image.altText: A dolphin calf lying on the sand.

props.synopsis: After three attempts and help from authorities, the juvenile dolphin returned to the water after beaching itself near Bunbury.

title.children: Fisherman's quick thinking leads to safe rescue of stranded dolphin calf

image.altText: White rocket launching amid plume of orange smoke.

props.synopsis: North Korea has tried and failed to launch a military satellite into space — a move that had threatened to violate United Nations conventions and further inflame tensions in the region.

title.children: North Korea's latest military satellite was a litmus test for Russian influence — then it exploded

image.altText: Rafael Nadal plays an overhead smash at the French Open.

props.synopsis: As he has done in every match he played, Rafael Nadal refuses to accept that his career is over until it's over, but his legacy as one of the greatest of all time is secure no matter how it ends.

title.children: 'The King is dead, long live the King': Why Rafael Nadal leaves a legacy that will never be touched

image.altText: AFL player Patrick Cripps speaking to umpire Mathew Nicholls. Cripps is pointing at himself and holding up an arm

props.synopsis: For a game that began with 10 rules written down in a pub in 1859, Australian football has been characterised by the evolution of those laws.

title.children: The Ambiguous Football League: Why Australian football's rules have always been up for debate

image.altText: A female reporter in a hijab and facemask interviews a survivor of floods in Baghlan province, Afghanistan.

props.synopsis: Climate change-induced flooding has left thousands of people in northern Afghanistan without homes or livelihoods.

title.children: Waiting for darkness to use the toilet: What life is like for women in flood-affected Afghanistan

image.altText: Macy Gray wearing black with her hands on either side of her face, natural hair

props.synopsis: Macy Gray has sold more than 25 million albums throughout her career — nine million of her debut album On How Life Is. She'll perform the entire album from start to finish when she tours Australia from July.

title.children: Macy Gray has given up on predicting hits, with the success of I Try taking her by surprise

image.altText: Digging with hands

props.synopsis: The Papua New Guinea government says more than 2,000 people are believed to have been buried alive in a landslide. But the remains of only six people have been recovered so far.

title.children: 'A situation that is getting worse': Why only six bodies of the thousands feared dead in PNG have been recovered

image.altText: Maryam Hamka

props.synopsis: Prosecutors told a Melbourne court that Maryam Hamka suffered repeated physical abuse at the hands of her boyfriend Toby Loughnane before her disappearance in 2021.

title.children: Death threats and repeated physical abuse alleged by prosecutors in Maryam Hamka murder trial

image.altText: Sunshine Private Hospital

props.synopsis: The 51-bed hospital in Melbourne's western suburbs had been open for just over a year before announcing its closure and the appointment of administrators.

title.children: Day surgeries cancelled and patients transferred as Melbourne private hospital enters voluntary administration

image.altText: A main street lined with shops and parked cars.

props.synopsis: It looks like business is booming the beautiful town of Daylesford, but the local council is grappling with a budget hit by inflation and cost-of-living pressures — and it's a situation that's said to be playing out across the state.

title.children: Fears for long-term viability of rural councils as popular Victorian tourist town faces financial woes
